componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Curt Launer with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just want to ask for some additional information with what you can tell us relative to Western Canada transmission and processing, is it about 20% of the overall earnings now? And the upside and Horn River and Montney seems a little bit more clear relativ
componenttext: Just want to ask for some additional information with what you can tell us relative to Western Canada transmission and processing, is it about 20% of the overall earnings now? And the upside and Horn River and Montney seems a little bit more clear relative to what's happening with the development at the Cabin Gas but also was offset by the Empress business, which continues to be troubled. So the magnitude of those things now that you're not reporting Empress separately is what I'd like to get a little bit more information about if we could.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. You know and expansion I think to continue to see this growth $30 million of new expansion EBIT that came in, in the quarter versus a year ago, and you will continue to see that rise through the projects come online, but that's a pretty healthy side
componenttext: Sure. You know and expansion I think to continue to see this growth $30 million of new expansion EBIT that came in, in the quarter versus a year ago, and you will continue to see that rise through the projects come online, but that's a pretty healthy side. No doubt, as you pointed out, we'd probably give up about that -- a little bit more at Empress but that has a limited downside, if you will. so I think you'll continue to see those type of increases quarter-over-quarter on the expansion side and you won't see that type of decline obviously at Empress. Even last year at full year last year was around $100 million at Empress. So that's the order of magnitude I guess if you wanted to be ultimately negative.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. The ultimate negative is sort of sounding like where we are now, so the next follow-up then becomes what would take for Empress to get anywhere near better here?
componenttext: Right. The ultimate negative is sort of sounding like where we are now, so the next follow-up then becomes what would take for Empress to get anywhere near better here?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well I think, 2 things. Obviously, more volumes out of Western Canada will be more helpful. But remember, one of the biggest -- there are 2 things. So that's an extraction premium issue on volumes. So that's about half impact. But the other half is just l
componenttext: Well I think, 2 things. Obviously, more volumes out of Western Canada will be more helpful. But remember, one of the biggest -- there are 2 things. So that's an extraction premium issue on volumes. So that's about half impact. But the other half is just low propane prices. So, obviously come again, because of the warm weather, you're going to have extremely low propane prices and that would have been about half of the impact of the negative perspective we saw this quarter over the last 4 quarters. And so I would expect this propane prices assuming that normal water to come back online.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Carl Kirst with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: Well maybe 2 cleanup questions if I could on union. The first is just, if you could just refresh my memory with the 5-year settlement kind of concluding this year. What's the timeframe of when we should be reaching something new with the Ontario regulators?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well I believe we just filed or we're just in a process of filing for next year. So you set a new base year, and we'd expect that to be settled obviously before you get into next year. And then, after that base year, so it would be another year out before
componenttext: Well I believe we just filed or we're just in a process of filing for next year. So you set a new base year, and we'd expect that to be settled obviously before you get into next year. And then, after that base year, so it would be another year out before you if you go down the room another 5-year rate deal. So you've got one year setting base rates, which I wouldn't -- we'll have to see how that shakes out. But I think we've seen a good benefit for consumers as well as shareholders. So I'd hope it would stick in the same range. But it's another year out before we determine if you are in a 5-year rate deal or something longer or something shorter.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that and then...
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that and then...

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Pat. The key thing we're going to seek in '13 and then through the 5 years and beyond in terms of preserving the incentives that we have in the existing 5-year structure. We're trying to thicken our equity comp point of capital structure and incre
componenttext: This is Pat. The key thing we're going to seek in '13 and then through the 5 years and beyond in terms of preserving the incentives that we have in the existing 5-year structure. We're trying to thicken our equity comp point of capital structure and increase our return on equity more in line with any B standards.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then just also on Union and just trying to kind of get a better sense of if you could quantify perhaps the weather impact given how, how historically warm it was. Only because since we were colder than normal last year, the EBIT shift isn
componenttext: Fair enough. And then just also on Union and just trying to kind of get a better sense of if you could quantify perhaps the weather impact given how, how historically warm it was. Only because since we were colder than normal last year, the EBIT shift isn't, favorably not as bad as we thought it would be. And so, I didn't know if there was anything else. I mean you cited sort of lower fuel cost but I didn't know if there was anything else in transmission or storage that was cushioning it that was sort of basically increasing that base business shall we say.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. The weather impact, you're right. It was more -- I'm always saying it's [ph] 100 year warmer weather, you'd be plus or minus 10% and I think we're obviously minus in that regard, and that's about where we were. We're at about $25 million down from a
componenttext: Yes. The weather impact, you're right. It was more -- I'm always saying it's [ph] 100 year warmer weather, you'd be plus or minus 10% and I think we're obviously minus in that regard, and that's about where we were. We're at about $25 million down from a weather perspective versus the year earlier. And then, that was partially offset, you benefited, $6 million to $8 million from just [ph] obviously by now pushing much gas through. So the net of those call it $17 million, $20 million kind of impact.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Chris Sighinolfi from UBS.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Chris Sighinolfi from UBS.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Greg, I'm just curious, you mentioned earlier a commentary about a recent trip to Asia, and we've been talking about the Western Canadian LNG export opportunity for some time. I guess I'm curious, we've seen a couple of facilities up there permitted by th
componenttext: Greg, I'm just curious, you mentioned earlier a commentary about a recent trip to Asia, and we've been talking about the Western Canadian LNG export opportunity for some time. I guess I'm curious, we've seen a couple of facilities up there permitted by the NAB and the federal government and I think you have a trade mission back in the fall. So as the discussions become more mature, are you able to tell me a little bit more of that sort of how they're progressing and sort of issues that are now being in focus as were the discussions become more mature?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think there's a couple of factors. One, and when we go over there, we see everybody from the trade houses to utilities. And this is the first trip that I personally had been on and also, investors, frankly. And the -- the issues are probably three
componenttext: Sure. I think there's a couple of factors. One, and when we go over there, we see everybody from the trade houses to utilities. And this is the first trip that I personally had been on and also, investors, frankly. And the -- the issues are probably threefold. So first of all, just they want to know who the pipeline potential carriers are, us and others, besides of the pie, if you will. And right now to kind of drawn pictures on maps, if you will, and how much that would cost. Two, they want to know our views and share their own views on what do you think the pricing mechanism is. Is it typical JCC, or is it going to be something of NIMEX, similar kind of the discussions you would see in the Gulf. And then lastly, and this is important one, and it's the political risk issue. Can you get projects permitted in a time that makes it relevant to the market. And so, on that regard it committed seems like both the BC government is very supportive from multiple corridors whether it's Prince Rupert or at their sites, like [ph] in it seems like the federal government is trying in Canada is trying to accelerate the whole regulatory review process for that. So that's the nature of the 3 discussions and of course, obviously, we also talked about our position in the Gulf. And our ability to build header systems into any and all the LNG facilities there, and storage. And so, that's the general nature of the discussion. As I've said, I think it's still a couple of years away before FID is made on many of these projects. And so people are really in the due diligence mode, both from provider of services, microeconomic sides and whether you could actually get things built.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair enough. I guess given the fact that you can speak about this issue for both a U.S. and a Canadian perspective when you're over there, can you give me a sense, if at all, if there's sort of an inclination that the Canadian government woul
componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. I guess given the fact that you can speak about this issue for both a U.S. and a Canadian perspective when you're over there, can you give me a sense, if at all, if there's sort of an inclination that the Canadian government would be more favorable or work faster than the U.S. government or vice versa or is it too early to say?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well I'd guess what I'd say, they're more concerned about political risks in the United States than they are in Canada. But there's no doubt they understand it's bigger building in Canada than it is in the U.S. So I don't think it means one way or the oth
componenttext: Well I'd guess what I'd say, they're more concerned about political risks in the United States than they are in Canada. But there's no doubt they understand it's bigger building in Canada than it is in the U.S. So I don't think it means one way or the other for different reasons there and you can see the various players in both British Columbia, West Coast of North America and the Gulf are often the similar players. So you see a lot of hedging of bets at this point in time.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I just want to follow-up very quickly on Greg's question earlier about Empress. We spoke I think around fourth quarter about your cautious optimism about sort of holding the line on some of these extraction premiums. Obviously, Greg, you
componenttext: Okay, great. And I just want to follow-up very quickly on Greg's question earlier about Empress. We spoke I think around fourth quarter about your cautious optimism about sort of holding the line on some of these extraction premiums. Obviously, Greg, you mentioned, the broken situation up there in the first quarter. I think you guys have had formerly around $100 million in EBIT in the guidance. Do you have any updated thoughts on where that might shake out or the things that you might do? Is there any I guess curiosity question, is there anything you can do this way to help mitigate those extraction premiums or is it just a volume situation?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well I think it's a volume situation. There's not a ton that we can do to make extraction premiums. I think the biggest thing is you have propane prices coming back vis-à-vis kind of improve weather and fundamentals on that side. Trying to get a few more
componenttext: Well I think it's a volume situation. There's not a ton that we can do to make extraction premiums. I think the biggest thing is you have propane prices coming back vis-à-vis kind of improve weather and fundamentals on that side. Trying to get a few more things for customers may help. But as I was looking at now, kind of more being the kind of $40 million range, probably $30 million to $40 million range for Empress to date. But again, that depends on if we get back to a normal overall year weather, that means you could see a very cold start to the winter in the fourth quarter and then that number is going to be lost. So we often, I know I often say this, but we really do often forget what a major impact weather does have across the entire value chain, and so we have see how that shakes out. But hopefully that gives you a little bit better color on it.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: Operator, is there another call?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: You do have a question from the line of Jonathan Capital.
componenttext: You do have a question from the line of Jonathan Capital.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Jonathan with Penta Co. I just wanted to focus for a moment on your MLP strategy that you discussed with Faisal as it relates to the U.S. Transmission assets and SE CPE. Over the last few years, we've seen guys like Williams Kindred target out One
componenttext: This is Jonathan with Penta Co. I just wanted to focus for a moment on your MLP strategy that you discussed with Faisal as it relates to the U.S. Transmission assets and SE CPE. Over the last few years, we've seen guys like Williams Kindred target out One Oak all shipped to the GP hold co strategy, which has unlocked a lot of value for them. And so I guess my question is, have you looked at or have you considered utilizing tax efficient 1031 exchange of your U.S. Transmission assets for SCP units with the idea that you could remove the growth CapEx off the parent's balance sheet and therefore, significantly increase the dividend growth rate at Spectra Corp., which is obviously a key value driver for a lot of your shareholders. So I guess I'm just curious if you've looked at it and if you have what are the key impediments when utilizing this strategy because clearly on paper, it appears to unlock a lot of value.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's couple of things. One, the big Canadian side of things, which is an important piece. So if I don't want to leave an orphan piece. Today, we've looked at it being from a hybrid perspective where we've got SCP, we've got DCP. I think the bigges
componenttext: I think it's couple of things. One, the big Canadian side of things, which is an important piece. So if I don't want to leave an orphan piece. Today, we've looked at it being from a hybrid perspective where we've got SCP, we've got DCP. I think the biggest value increment is actually on the DCP, DPM side of things. But there's no doubt, look, we always look at these things. We thought it was the big value piece in there. That would be something that we'd look closer at. I think the very low tax base of side of things. There's no doubt you could take back some units, but that's going to much from a cash perspective. And we think as we said that we can grow the dividend at a very healthy rate. In the C corp type structure, it gives us the balance of being able to utilize what would be a cheaper cost of debt at the corporate side of things while still being able to use SCP equity on the growth side. And would you've seen us with assets such as Gulfstream and other singular assets, if you will, with higher basis, those been opportunities to drive [ph] and we'll look at continuing to do those. And then the other issue I was saying the next year, that is at least something that I think one has to consider is the whole issue of tax reform. And that's something that we're watching cautiously. We've seen that happen in Canada where we had an MLP structure and then we saw corporate changes on that front that hurt the tax side of things. So for now, the focus is really at DCP. And moving those assets, which will benefit us obviously into BPM and they're building very large new pipelines on that front.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess just as a follow-up, if I may. You talked about tax reform, I guess there's a risk as well that if you don't move these assets in there, they'll be left at the parent, you could be at a competitive disadvantage relative to the peers who alr
componenttext: Right. I guess just as a follow-up, if I may. You talked about tax reform, I guess there's a risk as well that if you don't move these assets in there, they'll be left at the parent, you could be at a competitive disadvantage relative to the peers who already have moved and could potentially be grandfathered in that scenario as well. I'm just wondering how the board thinks about that risk.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: We haven't seen ourselves in the competitive disadvantage at this point that's for sure. Remember, a lot of other MLP structures were put in place and things a lot of it because they have a lot of cash they hadn't separated out businesses like E&P, et cet
componenttext: We haven't seen ourselves in the competitive disadvantage at this point that's for sure. Remember, a lot of other MLP structures were put in place and things a lot of it because they have a lot of cash they hadn't separated out businesses like E&P, et cetera. We haven't had that challenge. We separated in 2007 from Duke, and hadn't seen that. Now look, our history on MLPs is pretty clear. We've had a great history on MLPs. We do like to use them. We just to date have not seen the value it increment again, given the DCP side of things from a commodity perspective and given that 40% of our assets are in Canada. But obviously, all structures on the table and we look at that and if we thought that was the right way to go, that's something we'll definitely look at closely.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: The average $2.74 in the first quarter this year versus $4.11 last year. And then of course, we provide sensitivity for natural gas but as Greg said earlier, the primary impact there is on NGL gallons. That's the biggest move over at DCP. Ironically, of c
componenttext: The average $2.74 in the first quarter this year versus $4.11 last year. And then of course, we provide sensitivity for natural gas but as Greg said earlier, the primary impact there is on NGL gallons. That's the biggest move over at DCP. Ironically, of course, lower gas prices qualitatively can help transmission and distribution as long as we have decent weather. You probably saw the article in the Wall Street Journal earlier in the week about how dramatically power generators have shifted to natural gas and away from coal in the last just a few months and that's the trend that continues to accelerate. So there is some upside of lower and stable gas prices for us.

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And then if I could, when you think about the CapEx budget for this year, the timing of sanctioning any of the projects that you have is potential. Could that impact spending this year or is that going to more be push into the next year?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then my last question too is just all the questions about around how you're going to finance growth and restructuring and all that stuff. It would seem to me that really, a return on capital and cost of capital oversaw the important drivers here. And
componenttext: And then my last question too is just all the questions about around how you're going to finance growth and restructuring and all that stuff. It would seem to me that really, a return on capital and cost of capital oversaw the important drivers here. And when you think about acquisitions and you think about the returns that you're getting on your projects, can you sort of put that into context as it relates to 10% to 11% type of rosy target. How that compares with what you're thinking about on the MLP and then how that might impact your thinking about acquisitions?

headline: Spectra Energy Corp., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 04, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. Well obviously, again, when we look at DPM or SCP, I think you've seen us use the SCP or DPM equity to go out there and finance acquisitions. But we view C corp debt, which is obviously cheaper because you've got the tax shelter there. We
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. Well obviously, again, when we look at DPM or SCP, I think you've seen us use the SCP or DPM equity to go out there and finance acquisitions. But we view C corp debt, which is obviously cheaper because you've got the tax shelter there. We've continued to target 10% to 12% in returns in the last 3 years. You've seen us actually being about 14% type returns. DCP would even see higher teen returns in the activities that they've got on. So I think a hybrid model as we look at being able to use both C corps when that's the cheapest form of capital and MLPs when that's the cheapest form of capital actually, works well for our shareholders, and it works well for our unitholders at our MLPs. You've us do drop [ph], you've seen both at SCP and at DPM and you've seen us do acquisitions there. So I think it's the hybrid model that we see that allows us to get the best return overall for the unitholders and shareholders whether it's common or it's LP unitholders.
